entry.title: 最好的与第一
entry.content:
CNBC的故事2016年：

在犹他州参议员Orrin Hatch主持的一次对话中，在最近在犹他州技术巡回演唱会上的一次公开露面中，苹果首席执行官蒂姆·库克（Tim Cook）指出，微软在苹果几十年来的市场上有平板电脑。

库克强调了他的公司的时机推出了新产品，以强调公司成为最好的，第一个并充分利用给定产品的观点几乎是不可能的。 [...]

“如果我们仍然拥有最好的话，我们并不困扰我们。我们不会感到尴尬，因为我们花了更长的时间才能使它正确。”库克说。

“对于苹果来说，成为最好的是最重要的，到目前为止，其他两个人都胜过。”

数十年来，这一直是苹果的指导咒语，并且为公司提供了很好的服务。但是，当他们承诺第一位时，它就停止拿着水，但不是第一，也不是最好的。

如果您只承诺A，B和C-即使竞争对手发行X，Y和Z的版本，您的沉默也会自言自语。要么您认为X，Y和Z并不重要，要么，您认为值得花更多的时间使它们正确。但是，如果您承诺A，B，C，X，Y和Z，然后仅运送A，B和C，那么当竞争对手运送X，Y和Z时，您就会看起来迷失了。

entry.title: Google I/O 2025（5月20日至21日）的建议演示
entry.content:
杰伊·彼得斯（Jay Peters），上个月为The Verge：

该公司今天宣布，Google的下一次I/O开发人员会议将于5月20日和5月21日举行。该活动将“向在线所有人开放”，并将包括“直播主题和会议”。像过去几年一样，在加利福尼亚州山景城的海岸线露天剧场也将有一个面对面的组成部分。

这仍然两个月，但我对本周I/O的日期感兴趣。在我们录制了星期五的抖动之后（我们在上面谈论了我的“库比蒂诺州烂事”的作品，更重要的是，对它的反应，它似乎引起了人们的共鸣），我和我在吐出来，我吐了出来，它突然出现在我的脑海中，苹果的“更个性化的Siri”延迟是Google的营销礼物。

如果我在Google工作，我会做的是准备一个Google Gemini的现场演示，可以在Pixel Phone上进行苹果在去年在WWDC公告中展示的内容，然后在Apple从YouTube中撤出的Bella Ramsey TV广告中再次展示。这样的事情：

主持人：这是一个现场演示，在我的Pixel 9上。我需要在机场接我的妈妈，她给我发送了一封电子邮件，上面还有她的飞行信息。 [手里召集双子座... ]双子座，我妈妈的飞行降落是什么时候？

双子座：您妈妈的航班准时，并于11:30到达SFO。

主持人：我并不总是记得在日历中添加东西，所以我喜欢双子座可以帮助我跟踪我在休闲交谈中制定的计划，就像我妈妈在文字中提到的午餐预订一样。 [调用双子座... ]我们的午餐计划是什么？

双子座：您在12:30在水带享用午餐。

主持人：我们要花多长时间从机场到达那里？

双子座展示了一个Google Maps驱动方向弹出窗口，显示它需要21分钟。

然后，另一个现场演示与“我几个月前在咖啡馆格林内尔会见的那个家伙的名字是什么名字？”例如，苹果公司现在爆发的苹果情报广告的示例。完全相同的演示，但真实：生活和舞台。即使苹果从未承诺交付它们，这些演示也将是很棒的演示。但是鉴于苹果确实向今年承诺，并且现在将它们推迟到“来年”，那么如果Google可以告诉他们实际上在苹果自己的原始时间表上工作，那么他们会造成毁灭性。

坚持双子座实际上可以做的事情，在运行新Beta软件的实际像素电话上 -在某些帐户中，该软件已经包括Siri的延迟个性化功能。这一点应该显示Google AI技术，使用Google设备从Google Cloud Services访问个人数据，并根据一年前苹果公司做出的承诺。但是，Google的主持人不需要提及苹果或Siri，甚至不提及未命名的“竞争者”。每个观看I/O主题演讲的人都会认识到这些演示提示，并为自己得出竞争性结论。没有什么能像没有承认的那样自信，更不用说命名了。没有什么能像现场工作的演示那样证明。

entry.title: 全手Siri团队会议泄漏到彭博
entry.content:
马克·古尔曼（Mark Gurman），今天为彭博社报道：

Apple Inc.负责监督其Siri Virtual Assistant的顶级高管告诉员工，关键特征的延迟是丑陋而令人尴尬的，并且决定在该技术准备就绪之前公开推广这项技术。

罗比·沃克（Robby Walker）在苹果公司担任高级主任，他在Siri部门的全方位会议上发表了鲜明的评论，称该团队面临糟糕的时期。沃克还说，据了解此事的人说，目前尚不清楚增强能力何时会真正发起，因为这次聚会是私人的。

罗比·沃克（Robby Walker）不是苹果的“负责监督其Siri虚拟助手的顶级高管”。您选择这是高级副总裁John Giannandrea还是首席执行官Tim Cook，但Walker向Giannandrea报告。当然，古尔曼比我更了解这一点。我怀疑他知道苹果的整个组织图。但这使彭博社的标题 - “苹果的西里（Siri）酋长称AI延迟了丑陋而尴尬，承诺修复” - 误导。在这个标题中，沃克的这些评论显然并不是要泄漏的，这也有些误导。这不是公开道歉， 就像蒂姆·库克（Tim Cook）在2012年在iOS 6上发布苹果地图之后的一位蒂姆·库克（Tim Cook）所写并签署的那样。

尽管如此，他还是称赞该团队开发了“令人印象深刻的”功能，并誓言向消费者提供行业领先的虚拟助手。

这两个词是彭博报告的前九段中唯一的直接报价，这有点疯狂，因为古尔曼故事的后半部分充满了引号。我怀疑他的编辑对此确实不利。报价是多汁的AF，但直到第10段才真正开始。例如，例如，Walker认为Siri的功能“令人印象深刻”？没有鼻涕，我很想知道。是Siri的体育知识吗？新产品知识功能，为如何在设置中切换偏好提供了不完整和/或错误的说明？好的，我想这是一些杂耍，但我真诚而诚实地想知道哪个Siri是由Siri负责Siri的高级总监认为“令人印象深刻的”。

沃克在会议上告诉工作人员，延误特别“丑陋”，因为苹果已经公开展示了这些功能。他说：“这不是这些情况之一，我们可以在计划后向人们展示我们的计划。” “我们以前向人们展示。”

沃克说：“更糟的是，更糟的是，苹果的营销传播部门希望促进增强功能。

同样，这次会议显然并不是要泄漏。 （除了他们的产出质量外，也许是对Siri团队的又一次敲门声，他们会泄露内部会议。）但这是沃克（Walker）责备营销。

沃克还对即使达到当前发布期望也提出了怀疑。沃克说，尽管苹果的目标是iOS 19，但这并不意味着我们当时运输了。”沃克说。他说，该公司在开发方面还有更多优先事项，需要进行权衡。

沃克说：“我们在苹果公司对其他项目还有其他承诺。” “我们希望遵守对这些人的承诺，并且我们了解到这些人现在可能比推迟的特征更加紧张。”他说，随着明年计划的产品的进展，定时决定将按照“逐案”做出。

他说：“客户并不只期望这些新功能，但他们也想要一个更全面的Siri。” “我们将在准备就绪后立即运送这些功能。”

客户仍然没有得到开胃菜，但是是时候开始主菜了，因此厨房工作人员现在正在为此努力。但是不用担心，他们希望将开胃菜与甜点一起取出。但这没关系，因为甜点可能也迟到了。

据了解此事的人说，截至周五，苹果不打算立即对AI危机解雇任何高管。

我很想知道有多少人可能会熟悉这一特定问题。因为这个特殊的事情取决于蒂姆·库克在想什么。我认为这是他可能会讨论的六个人。等等，不，我只是想到了第七。我要说七个，上面。但是也许我错了，蒂姆·库克（Tim Cook）是健谈的人，他公开与许多高级管理人员交谈，他可能会开除谁。

沃克说，由于质量问题而延迟功能的决定，该公司发现该技术只能在80％到80％的时间内正常工作。他说，该小组“可以取得更大的进步来提高这些百分比，以便用户可以真正依靠一些东西。”

目前尚不清楚这些特征是指的，但据推测它们不是“令人印象深刻的”。因为当时“只能正常工作”的东西对我来说只是常规的印象，而不是令人印象深刻。也许是那些在五分之五的人不可思议的人？

沃克将这项工作与试图游泳前往夏威夷的努力进行了比较。他说：“我们游泳了数百英里 - 我们为游泳距离的世界纪录设置了一本吉尼斯书，但我们仍然没有游泳到夏威夷。” “我们正在跳下去，不是因为我们做过的令人惊叹的游泳，而是我们没有到达目的地的事实。”

我想说这更像是在包括在夏威夷停靠的巡航的客户门票，然后再也没有到达夏威夷，希望他们没有注意到何时何时返回港口到港口下船。

他在工作会议期间展示了示例：它能够在命令上找到他的驾驶执照号码并找到孩子的特定照片。他还展示了该技术如何通过语音控制精确地操纵应用程序。它嵌入了电子邮件中，添加了收件人并进行了其他更改。

这是报告中最大的实际新闻，也是第23段。

沃克说，一些工作人员可能会对延误感到“宽慰”。 “如果您在构建中使用这些功能，您可能会想知道：这些准备好了吗？我对将这些运送给客户的感觉如何？这是正确的选择吗？”

他补充说，一些员工“可能会感到尴尬”。

同样，我将重申这是一次私人会议，并不是要泄漏。也许这是一个不准确的摘要。我希望是。 But as reported by Gurman, this meeting reeks of you-all-deserve-participation-trophies-to-reward-your-hard-work-and-it's-OK-to-feel-embarrassed vibes.显然，需要什么“应该做什么？ /那么为什么他妈的不这样做呢？ “共鸣。

★

entry.title: Swift Assist尚未发货，尚未使用Beta
entry.content:
迈克尔·泰（Michael Tsai）：

Swift Assist应该在2024年到达，但它甚至从未出现在Beta中。苹果尚未宣布已推迟或取消。发行说明中甚至都没有提及。

苹果去年宣布了Xcode的两个AI驱动功能：预测代码完成和Swift Assist。预测代码的完成基本上是关于您接下来可能要写的内容的建议。 Swift Assist更加雄心勃勃，仅在云中运行（通过私有云计算），并承诺为您编写整个组件。如此之多，就像苹果智能的其余部分一样，这是发货的更简单的事情，而没有更激进的雄心勃勃的事情。

昨天，我本周在研究中调查了Swift Assist，并从WWDC检查了我的笔记，以了解我的长篇文章。去年，我与WWDC的Xcode团队进行了整个简报，las，我为此迟到了（以前的简报和另一支球队已经开始迟到），所以我错过了一些东西，我的笔记异常简洁。我想检查的笔记是去年6月是否向我展示了Swift Assist的现场演示。但是我的笔记没有说，我自己的记忆完全不确定我看到的演示是仅用于预测代码完成还是包括Swift Assist。

如果在这些WWDC简报中的其他人还记得是否真的对Swift Assis进行了演示，请告诉我。我真的很好奇Swift Assist是另一件事 - 就像所有“个性化的Siri”一样，它甚至在WWDC上都没有表现出来。

★

entry.summary: 谁决定这些个性化的Siri功能应该在WWDC主题演讲中发挥作用，并保证他们在来年就会到达，当时，他们处于未完成的状态，即使在受控的环境中，他们也无法将媒体演示给媒体？三个月后，谁决定苹果应该加倍并在电视广告中宣传这些功能，并将其作为iPhone 16阵容的卖点推广？
entry.content:
在我在这个球拍中的二十年中，我从来没有对自己错过一个故事比我在周五宣布的宣布的苹果智能的“更个性化的Siri”功能（原定出现在现在到现在的WWDC之间）的愤怒，这将被推迟到“来年”。

我应该检查头。

这一宣布令人惊讶，当然使我感到惊讶，但这从一开始就到了。我本来应该指出去年从WWDC开始的危险信号，我很尴尬，很抱歉，我从一开始就没有看到我应该很清楚的东西。

我错过了这是双重的。首先，苹果公司始终如一地运送预先宣布的产品和功能，让我感到自满。他们在这方面的记录并不完美，但是例外往往围绕边缘。 （没有人特别渴望苹果制作多个设备的电感充电垫，因此，当空气动力被证明是一个完整的破产时，它从来没有引起过多争议。对于Apple来说，将其AI功能贴上这样的伞术语是一个好主意，类似于一堆不同的功能，这些功能如何使不同的Apple设备互操作在“连续性”雨伞下。但是从技术上讲，没有这样的事情是“连续性”。并不是说Apple内部有一个名为Continuity.xcodeproj的Xcode项目，并且所有支持从Airdrop到Sidecar再到iPhone镜像再到剪贴板共享的代码都在代码的同一框架中实现。这是一个营销术语，但有用的术语 - 它有助于苹果解释这些功能，并帮助用户理解它们。

Even with everything Apple overpromised (if not outright lied about) at the WWDC keynote, the initial takeaway from WWDC from the news media was wrongly focused on their partnership with OpenAI. The conventional wisdom coming out of the keynote was that Apple had just announced something called “Apple Intelligence” but it was powered by ChatGPT, when in fact, the story Apple told was that they — Apple — had built an entire system called Apple Intelligence, entirely powered by Apple's own AI technology, and that it spanned from on-device execution all the way to a new Private Cloud Compute infrastructure they not only owned but are powering with their own custom-designed server hardware based on Apple Silicon chips. And that on top of all that, as a proverbial cherry on top, Apple also was adding an optional integration layer with ChatGPT.

So, yes, given that the news media gave credit for Apple's own actual announced achievements to OpenAI, Apple surely would have been given even less credit had they not announced the “more personalized Siri” features. 'So Why the Fuck Doesn't It Do That?'

In May 2011, Fortune published an extraordinary look inside Apple by Adam Lashinsky , at what we now know to be the peak, and (alas) end, of the Steve Jobs era. The piece opens thus:

Apple doesn't often fail, and when it does, it isn't a pretty sight at 1 Infinite Loop. In the summer of 2008, when Apple launched the first version of its iPhone that worked on third-generation mobile networks, it also debuted MobileMe, an e-mail system that was supposed to provide the seamless synchronization features that corporate users love about their BlackBerry smartphones. MobileMe was a dud. Users complained about lost e-mails, and syncing was spotty at best. Though reviewers gushed over the new iPhone, they panned the MobileMe service.

Steve Jobs doesn't tolerate duds. Shortly after the launch event, he summoned the MobileMe team, gathering them in the Town Hall auditorium in Building 4 of Apple's campus, the venue the company uses for intimate product unveilings for journalists. According to a participant in the meeting, Jobs walked in, clad in his trademark black mock turtleneck and blue jeans, clasped his hands together, and asked a simple question:

“Can anyone tell me what MobileMe is supposed to do?” Having received a satisfactory answer, he continued, “So why the fuck doesn't it do that?”

For the next half-hour Jobs berated the group. “You've tarnished Apple's reputation,” he told them. “You should hate each other for having let each other down.” The public humiliation particularly infuriated Jobs. Walt Mossberg, the influential Wall Street Journal gadget columnist, had panned MobileMe. “Mossberg, our friend, is no longer writing good things about us,” Jobs said. On the spot, Jobs named a new executive to run the group.

    That's about 40 seconds of keynote time I bet Federighi regrets — and that I suspect he was skeptical about including. It's telling though, that unlike WWDC, Apple didn't show those features or spend even a full minute talking about at the iPhone 16 event — despite the fact that, ostensibly, those features should have been three months closer to shipping than they were in June. Federighi's title is SVP of software, and Apple Intelligence and Siri are “software”, but John Giannandrea (SVP of machine learning and AI strategy) is Federighi's peer, not subordinate, on the org chart — both report directly to Tim Cook — and is responsible for Siri and Apple Intelligence. Why it was Federighi, not Giannandrea, pitching those features in the iPhone 16 event keynote almost certainly comes down to Federighi's presentation skills and stage presence, not responsibility for the features themselves. But assuming marketplaces meet all requirements, I think users in both places will eventually be able use eg AltStore PAL and Epic Games Store.

entry.title: Simon Willison on the Privacy/Security Risks of Personalized Siri, vis-à-vis Prompt Injection
entry.content:
Simon Willison:

These new Apple Intelligence features involve Siri responding to requests to access information in applications and then performing actions on the user's behalf.

This is the worst possible combination for prompt injection attacks! Any time an LLM-based system has access to private data, tools it can call and exposure to potentially malicious instructions (like emails and text messages from untrusted strangers) there's a significant risk that an attacker might subvert those tools and use them to damage or exfiltrate a user's data.

I published this piece about the risk of prompt injection to personal digital assistants back in November 2023, and nothing has changed since then to make me think this is any less of an open problem.

Prompt injection seems to be a problem that LLM providers can mitigate, but cannot completely solve. They can tighten the lid, but they can't completely seal it. But with your private information, the lid needs to be provably sealed — an airtight seal, not a “ well, don't turn it upside down or shake it ” seal. So a pessimistic way to look at this personalized Siri imbroglio is that Apple cannot afford to get this wrong, but the nature of LLMs' susceptibility to prompt injection might mean it's impossible to ever get right. And if it is possible, it will require groundbreaking achievements. It's not enough for Apple to “catch up”. They have to solve a vexing problem — as yet unsolved by OpenAI, Google, or any other leading AI lab — to deliver what they've already promised.

So Apple had promised for this year — and oft promoted — an entire set of features that they not only have now acknowledged will not ship this year, but which they might, in fact, never be able to ship. Makes me wonder how many people inside Apple were voicing these concerns a year ago, and why they lost the debate to start promising these features last June and advertising them in September.

★

entry.summary: This announcement is disappointing, but unsurprising. If it's Apple's general policy not to ship a product before it's ready, that applies tenfold for a product involving LLM access to deeply private on-device information.
entry.content:
Here's a statement I got this morning from Apple spokeswoman Jacqueline Roy, verbatim:

“Siri helps our users find what they need and get things done quickly, and in just the past six months, we've made Siri more conversational, introduced new features like type to Siri and product knowledge, and added an integration with ChatGPT.我们还一直在研究一个更个性化的Siri，使其对您的个人背景有了更多的了解，以及在您的应用程序内部和跨应用程序中采取行动的能力。 It's going to take us longer than we thought to deliver on these features and we anticipate rolling them out in the coming year.”

This is a Friday sort of wah-waaah sad-trombone news drop, but it's good that Apple is getting on top of it, and setting expectations accurately.

Reading between the lines, and based on my PhD-level fluency in Cupertino-ese, what Apple is saying here is that these “more personalized Siri” features are being punted from this year's OS cycle to next year's: to iOS 19 and MacOS 16. Apple's years in this context aren't calendar years, but Apple's OS product years. Those years effectively start at WWDC. The problem, from Apple's perspective, messaging-wise, is that they don't talk about future products. They haven't officially acknowledged there is going to be an iOS 19 or MacOS 16. They haven't even yet announced that there's going to be a WWDC 2025. But they do want to set expectations accurately, especially for a feature as high profile — from Apple's own marketing push — as Apple Intelligence.所以我们在这里。

It was already pretty obvious these features weren't coming in iOS 18.4/MacOS 15.4, because they're not in the developer betas that are already out. And if these features were coming in iOS 18.5/MacOS 15.5, or even iOS 18.6/MacOS 15.6, Apple wouldn't have felt the need to issue this “It's going to take us longer than we thought...” statement today. Delivering the “more personalized Siri” in iOS 18.5 or even 18.6 would have been delivering them on the originally announced schedule — the “coming year” that began with WWDC 2024. That would have been the tail end of that “year”, but within it. But Apple, being limited to the self-imposed opaque verbiage of Cupertino-ese, isn't going to spell that out. But trust me, you can bank on it: what they're announcing today is that these features are coming in iOS 19/MacOS 16.

Siri在今年的OS周期（iOS/iPados 18 + MacOS 15红杉）中的苹果智能伞下的几种有用但迭代的方法有所改善，但是去年6月在WWDC上展出的大型“个性化的Siri”是Siri相关的Apple Intelligence，这些东西是人们，人们对此很兴奋，最令人兴奋。 This is the “ App Intents ” stuff — the features requiring Siri to have access to and, effectively, understanding of your personal information, in your apps, stored privately on your devices. These are the most helpful-sounding, most practical, most futuristic features of Apple Intelligence. And they're the sort of features Apple is almost uniquely positioned to offer, alongside only Google, as the provider of a mobile platform and device ecosystem.

From Apple's own announcement , after the WWDC keynote:

Siri will be able to deliver intelligence that's tailored to the user and their on-device information. For example, a user can say, “Play that podcast that Jamie recommended,” and Siri will locate and play the episode, without the user having to remember whether it was mentioned in a text or an email. Or they could ask, “When is Mom's flight landing?” and Siri will find the flight details and cross-reference them with real-time flight tracking to give an arrival time.

“When is Mom's flight landing?” is easily understood, by we humans, and a really good example of the sort of Siri interaction that would be obviously useful. But you can also pretty easily see how complex it is on Apple's side. Siri has long been able to do the “Mom” thing. Your spouse, your kids — you've long able to tell Siri to call or text those people by nickname like that. But getting your mom's flight information out of your email (which I think was the premise of this demo in the WWDC keynote — that the flight info was stored in a message in Mail) or from text messages, and then knowing how to check for current flight status information for that flight, is something far beyond the ken of current Siri. Getting the information requires access to your most personal information — your own email and messages. Getting the correct information from your messages requires the common sense of understanding that you're obviously asking about some sort of current trip your mom is taking, not, say, an email she sent you about a flight back in 2019, or one from 2022, or even one from December last year. The Siri we currently know lacks that sort of common sense . And then lastly, after getting the correct flight from your email, performing this task requires Siri to have the agency to go look up the current status of that particular flight — and get it right every time it provides an answer.

If Siri answers, “Your mom's flight is arriving at 4:30 this afternoon, and it's currently showing an on-time arrival,” you really want that information to be correct if you've promised to pick her up at the airport. You'll be annoyed if you drive to the airport and it turns out she's not actually landing until 7:30. And you'll be in real trouble if she's landing at 1:30 and you show up three hours later, having banked on Siri's answer being accurate.

至少可以说，苹果宣布产品延迟是非常不寻常的。 1 The white iPhone 4 was supposed to debut alongside the black one in June 2010, but, bizarrely, was delayed several times ( which I had fun with more than once ) and wound up not shipping until the end of April the next year , 10 months late. The original AirPods were announced alongside the iPhones 7 in September 2016, and were supposed to ship in October. They wound up being delayed until December. Apple's statement in October 2016, regarding the AirPods being delayed, as given to Matthew Panzarino at TechCrunch :

“The early response to AirPods has been incredible. We don't believe in shipping a product before it's ready, and we need a little more time before AirPods are ready for our customers.”

This is exactly why Apple hews to an almost religious policy of not announcing products before they're ready. When they do make exceptions — when they lapse, as it were, as cited above ( and below ) — they often regret it. You can't break a promise you never made, and you can't miss a ship date you never announced. Even with talented teams and realistic managers, there's often a long span between how long you expect a project to take and how long it actually winds up taking. Engineering schedules often slip even with predictable technologies, and the non-deterministic nature of LLMs makes their future inherently unpredictable.

Most of Apple Intelligence has felt like Apple has pushed it out a year ahead of the company's usual level of baked-ness. I've held all year long that if the entire industry — along with Wall Street — weren't in the midst of a generative-AI/LLM mania, that “Apple Intelligence” wouldn't have been announced until this year's WWDC, not last year's.今天的宣布令人失望，但对我来说毫不奇怪。 The Siri integration with personal data through App Intents has never felt like something that was going to be ready for real customer usage in this year's OS cycle. And if it's Apple's general policy not to ship a product before it's ready, that applies tenfold for a product involving LLM access to deeply private on-device information. It's better to ship late, but ready, than to ship something unfinished or unreliable to hit a promised deadline. And with something like next-generation Siri, I'd say that's downright essential. Apple can take the bad publicity today's announcement is engendering; they cannot afford to squander the trust of their users.

  1. The granddaddy of modern-era Apple product delays, of course, is AirPower — the multi-device (iPhones, Apple Watch, AirPods) charging device that Apple pre-announced in September 2017, alongside the iPhone X and iPhone 8. When announced, Apple said AirPower would ship in “2018”. It wound up never shipping, but the plug wasn't officially pulled (so to speak) until 29 March 2019 , an absurd 18 months after it was announced. ↩︎

entry.summary: From the perspective of a company the size of Disney, it would cost veritable pennies to keep FiveThirtyEight's website around forever.多么耻辱。
entry.content:
Oliver Darcy, reporting at Status (paywalled, alas), on the sudden demise of FiveThirtyEight :

On Wednesday morning, shortly after sending an all-staff memo announcing layoffs at ABC News, network president Almin Karamehmedovic joined a virtual meeting with the FiveThirtyEight team. ABC新闻拥有的政治分析网站上的15名员工通过华尔街日报的报告了解到了前一天晚上，他们被放开了。 Now, they were hearing it from Karamehmedovic himself.

但是，像其他经理在当天在ABC新闻上进行大规模裁员的其他经理人一样，对此几乎没有话要说。 I'm told he appeared to be reading from a script as he delivered the devastating news. He offered no explanation for why the Disney-owned network had decided to shutter FiveThirtyEight, which it acquired in 2018 along with data whiz and then-editor Nate Silver. He took no questions. He simply thanked the employees for their work, told them a human resources staffer would follow up, and ended the meeting.有人告诉我，整个事件持续了大约15分钟。 Soon after, employees had their access to ABC News' systems shut off and the FiveThirtyEight website was pulled offline . Just like that, it was over.

业务是业务，裁员和关闭绝不是创伤。但是，有一种正确的方法可以做事和错误的方法。错误的方法之一是让工作人员发现自己都通过阅读《华尔街日报》而被解雇。这个家伙Karamehmedovic听起来像是一个真正的A级笨蛋。

与这些公司关闭网站时毫不客气地插入插件的公司怎么办？ Why not keep the FiveThirtyEight site up and running — at least for a while, if not in perpetuity? It costs practically nothing to run a server for a static/archived website.我不明白。 It betrays a profound level of disrespect for the work that the site hosted.如果他们想关闭FiveThirtyeight作为一个持续的关注，这是ABC的业务，但是多年的工作值得保持在线，这都是出于对那些成立次数的人的尊重以及可能仍然想提及它的观众的尊重。迪士尼没有像Touchstone Pictures这样关闭的子公司工作室燃烧电影。

旧的印刷世界与在线出版的新世界之间存在着巨大的鸿沟。 The difference is profound, but largely overlooked, because it's human nature to just adapt to the nature of different forms of media and quickly accept current media forms as “normal”. With print, issues were largely ephemeral to the audience. You'd get a newspaper every day, and magazines every week or month, and you'd throw them out after you'd finished reading them. If you wanted to look back at what the paper had published about something a year, a month, or even just a few days ago, you were out of luck, in terms of being able to just look it up on the spot. Librarians did the yeoman's work of archiving newspapers and magazines to microfilm, so nothing was truly gone or forgotten, but it was an enormous hassle to access microfilm archives. You pretty much had to know the dates of the issues you wanted to see, and you had to do the “searching” with your eyeballs, page by page. The ability of anyone, today, to just instantly access week-, month-, year-, and even decades-old stories is a breathtaking advantage of web publications. And for the last 15 years or so, we've had the ability to do this from little machines we all carry in our pockets everywhere we go.这是真的很棒。

但是关闭Web出版物时的标准行为就是仅拉插头。当整个公司陷入困境时，那是一回事。 But when there's a parent company, especially a thriving one, there's no justification for pulling the plug other than spiteful disregard for the work. From the perspective of a company the size of Disney, it would cost veritable pennies to keep FiveThirtyEight's website around forever.多么耻辱。

Apple Announces, With Much Surprise, Mac Studios With M4 Max and M3 Ultra (!) Chips
entry.content:
Jason Snell, at Six Colors:

With the M4 Mac mini being powerfully tempting for desktop Mac users who crave power, Apple has upgraded the Mac Studio to blast past the mini in terms of performance. The base model, still starting at $1999, is powered by the M4 Max chip previously available only in the M4 MacBook Pro . And the new high-end Mac Studio, starting at the same $3999 price tag, is powered by a monstrous chip with 32 CPU cores (including 24 performance cores) and up to 80 GPU cores. It's a chip never seen before anywhere — the M3 Ultra.

你听到了我。 For Apple's fastest Mac ever — and it's clear that it will be — Apple's shipping a chip based on two high-end chips (fused together with Apple's UltraFusion technology) from Apple's previous processor generation. Weird, right? It seems like a few things are going on here: first, that the development of the Ultra chip takes longer and that Apple won't commit to shipping an Ultra chip in every chip generation. Second, that the first-generation three-nanometer chip process of Apple's chipmaking partner, TSMC, isn't as dead and buried as generally thought. Just this week Apple also introduced an iPad Air with an M3 processor, and of course the new iPad mini shipped with an A17 Pro processor based on the same process.

This M3/M4 generational fork — the M3 Ultra chip debuting in new Mac Studio models alongside the M4 Max — was so unexpected that, during my embargoed press briefing about the news yesterday, I thought the Apple rep misspoke when he said M3, not M4, for the Ultra models. But no, the Ultra chip really is a generation behind. When asked the obvious question — why — Apple's answer was straightforward: the Ultra chips take a lot longer to engineer.

The M4 Max Studio models are, computationally, equivalent (exactly, I think) with the M4 Max MacBook Pros that debuted October 30 , maxing out (no pun intended) at 16 CPU cores, 40 GPU cores, 8 TB of storage, and 128 GB of RAM. The M4 Max Studio models start at $2,000, but that starting price only gets you a 14-core CPU, 32-core GPU, 16-core Neural Engine, 512 GB of storage, and a measly 36 GB of RAM.

The intriguing M3 Ultra models start at $4,000, which gets you a 28-core CPU, 60-core GPU, 32-core Neural Engine, 1 TB of storage, and a healthy 96 GB of RAM. Available upgrades to, uh, ultra out the Ultra models:

  • 32-core CPU + 80-core GPU: +$1,500
  • 256 GB of RAM: +$1,600
  • 512 GB of RAM: +$4,000 (only available with the 32-core CPU/80-core GPU)

entry.summary: 这个“功能”对包括流媒体服务在内的任何人都没有实现任何价值，但对诚实的人施加了巨大的（对于大多数人来说，令人困惑和令人沮丧），只是试图轻松捕获高质量的人（而不是用他们该死的手机拍摄他们的反射性笔记本电脑展示的照片）。
entry.content:
诺拉·德利格特（Nora Deligter），于2023年6月为屏幕板岩撰写“屏幕截图”：

About five years ago, Catherine Pearson started taking screenshots of every bouquet featured on The Nanny (1993–1999), the six-season CBS sitcom that was then streaming on Netflix. She was just becoming a florist, and she found the arrangements — ornate, colorful, and distinctly tropical — inspirational. She now keeps them in a folder on her desktop, alongside screenshots of flower arrangements featured on Poirot (1989–2013), the British detective drama. A few months ago, however, Pearson suddenly found that when her fingers danced instinctively toward Command-Shift-3, she was greeted by a black box where her flowers used to be, a censored version of what she had meant to capture.

大约在这个时候，Netflix，HBO Max，Amazon Prime等流媒体平台在屏幕截图上施加了一个安静的禁运。起初，有解决方法：用户可以通过使用浏览器勇敢或下载扩展名或Fireshot（例如Fireshot）来继续屏幕截图。 But gradually, the digital-rights-management tech adapted and became more sophisticated. Today, it is nearly impossible to take a screenshot from the most popular streaming services, at least not on a Macintosh computer. [...]

对于PC用户，这个故事需要不同，更快乐的转弯。 With the use of Snipping Tool — a utility exclusive to Microsoft Windows, users are free to screen grab content from all streaming platforms. This seems like a pointed oversight, a choice on the part of streamers to exclude Mac users (though they make up a tiny fraction of the market) because of their assumed cultural class.这个假设不是不合理的。 Out of everyone interviewed for this article, only one of them was a PC user.

自从她在2023年出版以来，Deligter的文章就坐在我的漫长（且不断增长的）列表中。

我不确定这是什么技术答案，但是在MacOS上，它似乎涉及GPU和视频解码硬件。 These DRM blackouts happen at such a low level that no high-level software — any sort of utility you might install — can route around them. I think Windows still offers easy screenshotting of frames from DRM video not because the streaming services somehow don't care about what Windows users do (which, when you think about it, would be a weird thing not to care about, given Windows's market share), but because Windows uses a less sophisticated imaging pipeline.或者也许不是不那么复杂的，更准确地说整合的整合是更准确的。这些DRM停电在Apple设备上（您无法从iPhone或iPad上的DRM视频中捕获屏幕截图）通过OS和硬件之间的深入集成启用，从而使停电在硬件级别上强加。 And I don't think the streaming services opt into this screenshot prohibition other than by “protecting” their video with DRM in the first place.如果视频受到DRM保护，则无法屏幕截图；如果不是，您可以。

On the Mac, it used to be the case that DRM video was blacked-out from screen capture in Safari, but not in Chrome (or the dozens of various Chromium-derived browsers). But at some point a few years back, you stopped being able to capture screenshots from DRM videos in Chrome, too — by default . But in Chrome's Settings page, under System, if you disable “Use graphics acceleration when available” and relaunch Chrome, boom, you can screenshot everything in a Chrome window, including DRM video. You can go to the magic URL chrome://gpu/ before and after toggling this setting to see a full report on the differences — as you'd expect, it turns off all hardware acceleration for video encoding/decoding, compositing, and more. You wouldn't want to browse like this all the time (certainly not on battery power), but it's a great trick to know for capturing stills from videos.

我不明白的是，为什么Apple首先会为硬件加速视频而烦恼（这都是iOS平台上的视频 - 没有解决方法，例如在iPhone或iPad上使用硬件加速度使用硬件加速度）。没有人会创建一个由DRM保护的视频创建的盗版副本。 And it's not like this “feature” in MacOS and iOS has put an end to bootlegging DRM-protected video content.这个“功能”对包括流媒体服务在内的任何人都没有实现任何价值，但对诚实的人施加了巨大的（对于大多数人来说，令人困惑和令人沮丧），只是试图轻松捕获高质量的人（而不是用他们该死的手机拍摄他们的反射性笔记本电脑展示的照片）。

entry.title: ★ Why Can't We Screenshot Frames From DRM-Protected Video on Apple Devices?

entry.summary: The iPhone 16e is an iPhone for people who don't want to think much about their phone. But they *do* want an iPhone, not just any “whatever” phone. A just plain iPhone, with a good screen, good enough (and simple) camera, and great battery life.
entry.content:
I've spent the last six days using the iPhone 16e, and the experience has been a throwback. In many ways, the iPhone 16e both looks and feels like the modern-day progeny of the early Steve Jobs era iPhones. Early iPhones like the plastic 3G and 3GS, and the glass-back/metal-sides 4 and 4S were simpler offerings. Two colors, black and white. Single-lens inconspicuous cameras. iPhone 16e感觉就像他们的直接后代。

让我们从相机开始。 With just a single lens on the back, the iPhone 16e camera doesn't just look less conspicuous compared to its dual- and triple-lens brethren, it feels less conspicuous.尤其是对我来说，来自日常驾驶iPhone Pro型号的几年，16e的手和口袋的感觉非常小，因为它缺少iPhone 16和16 Pro摄像机镜头进一步伸出的整个“ Mesa”突出。

Apple's tech specs for iPhone thickness don't include the camera lenses or camera mesas.苹果只是测量并报告手机平坦非摄像机部分的厚度。但是那些相机模块和镜头伸出了很多。 Using a digital caliper, I measured the thickness of the three “levels” of the 16e, regular 16, and 16 Pro:

根据台面镜头
iPhone 16e 7.8mm - 9.5mm
iPhone 16 7.8mm 9.6mm 11.3mm
iPhone 16 Pro 8.3mm 10.3mm 12.5mm

因此，16e不仅完全省略了台面，而且从镜头到前显示器的整个相机的厚度都比其台面上的iPhone 16和iPhone 16 Pro的厚度小，甚至不包括镜头。

只需查看Apple比较页面中的此屏幕截图，以显示所有三个并排的黑色选项：

iPhone 16e看起来像是一部手机，背面带有微型相机。 iPhone 16 Pro看起来像是一部恰好是手机的相机。您也确实可以感觉到手头上的差异 - 不仅是体重，而且平衡。 1您可以感觉到16个Pro的额外相机硬件增加了额外的重量。 Per Apple's specs, the iPhone 16e weighs 167g; 16 Pro 199g - 差异16％。 （还要注意一个聪明的触摸：苹果的每个手机的默认壁纸，巧妙地表明它们拥有多少个相机镜头。）

16e相机镜头并没有与手机的背面冲洗，但是它很少（按我的尺寸为1.7毫米）突出，以至于它可以回到iPhone摄像头刚开始从手机后面伸出的时候。 The 16e still wobbles when laid on a tabletop, but dramatically less than a regular iPhone 16 or especially the iPhone 16 Pro, whose camera module seems downright bulbous in comparison.但是16e的1.7毫米相机镜头的突起是如此之最小，以至于在案例中，手机确实完全平放在桌子上，因为盒子不需要保护镜头，因为16e相机镜头的突出小于壳体的厚度。 (Apple included two of its $39 Silicone Cases with my review kit, in blue and black. They're fine, and feel exactly like Apple's usual Silicone Cases.)

由于最近的常规和Pro iPhone型号上的“宏”模式使用了0.5×Ultrawide摄像头，因此16E没有次级镜头，因此16E没有宏模式。从iPhone 13 Pro开始，宏模式使iPhone Pros可以专注于小于一英寸的物体。但是，由于16e的1倍相机的传感器比更昂贵的iPhone型号上的1×相机具有较小的传感器和较小的镜头，因此它能够以较短的距离进行焦点，而不是那些更大，更好的1×相机。 iPhone 16 Pro上的1倍摄像头的最小聚焦距离为24厘米（〜9.5英寸）。 The 1× camera on an iPhone 16e has a minimum focus distance of 12cm (~4.75 inches). Actual macro mode (on regular and Pro iPhone models) is better, but you don't need it as much when the 16e's lone camera can focus on objects at half the distance, just over 4 inches away, in its regular shooting mode.

当然，16e的不起眼的相机具有价格：图像质量。 You can really see the difference in low light. The 16e camera is slower (resulting in blurry images with subjects in motion) and images are noisier.当卤化物中的过程为零时，在低光中拍摄时，差异尤其明显。不过，这是一个很好的相机，出于刻痕目的。对于大多数可能正在考虑使用iPhone 16e的人，它可能是他们拥有的最好的相机。 And there's something to be said for the simplicity of just one lens, offering 1× and 2× fields of view. If you know what an ƒ-stop is, you probably shouldn't buy an iPhone 16e.如果您不知道什么是ƒ停车，则可能不会注意到iPhone 16甚至16 Pro的相机质量有任何差异。对于只想要一个体面的相机的任何人来说，这是一个完美的相机。

缺少的是：magsafe，晋升和超宽带（以及，其他超宽带）

Peruse Apple's comparison page , comparing the 16e to the 16 Pro and regular 16, and you'll spot dozens of small differences.但是，一个遗漏吸引了最大的关注（并产生了最“ WTF Apple？”反应）是Magsafe。我拥有一堆Magsafe外围设备，而没有它，个人就不会购买iPhone。我的桌子上有一个码头（备用模式很棒），床头柜上的充电器，以及像这种磁性折叠台这样的方便的doodads。使用16e作为我的主要手机的一周，我仍然像第一天晚上一样想念Magsafe。

但是据苹果代表称，16e目标受众中的大多数人专门将手机插入充电电缆中。他们倾向于根本不使用电感充电，而当他们这样做时，他们可能不在乎16e被pokey 7.5W QI充电速度粘住，而最近更昂贵的iPhone在15W甚至25W时通过Magsafe充电。对我来说，这不是我最想念的高充电速度。这是捕获的位置。 2我认为苹果比我更了解16e的预期受众。大胆的火球读者不在16e人群中；是DF读者的朋友和家人。

典型的低端iPhone买家关心哪些功能？他们想要一部看起来不错的手机，具有良好的显示屏，不错的相机和较长的电池寿命。他们是否在乎16e仅支持Wi-Fi 6，而不是7？不，因为他们的想法为零，Wi-Fi版本号甚至是什么意思。他们只是认为Wi-Fi是Wi-Fi。他们是否关心Verizon（又称“ Ultra宽带”）的SuperSpeed MMWave 5G网络？不。他们只是希望他们的细胞连接快速而牢固。 （我来自Apple的评论单位在AT＆T蜂窝连接上暂时持续了良好的ESIM。整个星期，我唯一注意到一个较弱的信号是在一个深处的郊区 /边界乡村地区，而周末拜访家人；我妻子的iPhone 15 Pro Max在同​​一位置的Verizon上失去了信号。我对Apple的C1 C1调制仪的投诉。）

iPhone 16E还省略了另一个“超宽带” ，这是苹果用于精确位置检测的芯片 - 例如跟踪AirPod到一英尺内。精确发现非常酷，当您真正被诸如钥匙扣之类的丢失物品​​所困扰时，非常有帮助。自2019年iPhone 11以来，除了SE（现在是16E）以外的所有新iPhone（现在是16e），Ultra Gidband已包含在所有新的iPhone中。从书呆子的角度来看，五年后的16E确实确实是一个奇怪的遗漏。 But how many people in your extended family know what “ultra wideband precision finding” is?

迄今为止，只有Apple的iPhone Pro模型才支持促销 - Apple的营销名称具有自适应刷新率，最高为120 Hz且可在“始终处”显示模式下达到1 Hz。鉴于常规的iPhone 16（和16 Plus）不支持促销，因此16e的机会为零。有具有高率速率显示器的中端Android手机，但是（a）我认为它们没有更好的显示器，考虑到所有内容，并且（b）它们是中端Android手机。这就像吹嘘起亚Sorento中仪表板显示器上的刷新率。 16e显示器还具有一个倒退的档次，代替了更典型，更有趣，有时巧妙的充满活力的岛屿。

iPhone 16e的目标是“我只关心基础知识” iPhone买家：屏幕看起来不错，相机很好，但简单，电池持续很长时间（对于从四岁或五岁的iPhone升级的任何人来说，差异都非常明显），它运行了所有现有的应用程序，并且在插入USB电缆时会快速充电。这些是基础知识，基础知识都是休闲用户关心的。由于其最小突出的单相机镜头，它的重量较轻，体重较小。

定价

16e获得的讨论的唯一方面比其遗漏MagSafe的讨论更多的是其128 GB基本型号的起价为600美元。有些人说：“这应该少$ 100”，他们往往是同一个人，他们也强烈认为应该包括Magsafe和促销展示。这是苹果当前的iPhone阵容，加上已停产（但仍然可以从某些承运人那里获得）3rd Generation SE：

The iPhone 16e is an iPhone for people who don't want to think much about their phone.但是他们确实想要iPhone，而不仅仅是任何“任何”手机。 A just plain iPhone, with a good screen, good enough (and simple) camera, and great battery life.我认为苹果用iPhone 16E钉了钉子。

  1. 16e的侧轨也有一个决定的感觉。双方比常规16和16 Pro（以及15/15 Pro，以及14/14 Pro ...）感到更清晰，更圆润。本身本身，这种平方（尖锐的角度吗？）不是很糟糕的，但是它确实传达了16e是一个不太优质的设备的感觉。 ↩︎
